## Arpeggio: Major 7th in C (Shape: G)

### Brief Presentation
An arpeggio is a musical technique where notes in a chord are played individually in a sequence rather than together. The Major 7th arpeggio in C, played in the shape of G, consists of the notes C-E-G-B. This arpeggio creates a lush, dreamy sound that is commonly used in jazz, R&B, funk, and other genres to add color and complexity to chord progressions.

### Notes and Intervals
- C (Root)
- E (Major 3rd)
- G (Perfect 5th)
- B (Major 7th)

### Genre Usage and Musical Flavor
The Major 7th arpeggio in C, played in the shape of G, is often used in genres like jazz, R&B, and funk to create a sophisticated and harmonically rich sound. The addition of the Major 7th interval (B in this case) gives the arpeggio a smooth and dreamy quality, adding a touch of tension and resolving back to the root note, C.

### Songs
1. "So What" by Miles Davis - This iconic jazz piece features the Major 7th arpeggio in C played in various chord voicings throughout the song.
2. "Isn't She Lovely" by Stevie Wonder - The intro to this classic R&B tune showcases the Major 7th arpeggio in C, providing a lush and soulful sound.
3. "I Wish" by Stevie Wonder - The funky guitar parts in this song incorporate the Major 7th arpeggio in C, adding a jazzy flair to the composition.
